ch.ethz.csb.youscope.shared.measurement.callback
Interface MeasurementCallback

All Superinterfaces:
java.rmi.Remote
All Known Subinterfaces:
RemoteScriptEngineManager, WaitForUserMeasurementCallback
All Known Implementing Classes:
WaitForUserCallbackImpl
public interface MeasurementCallback
extends java.rmi.Remote

A measurement callback can be used by a measurement to gain control over functionality at creation time. Typically, it is used by measurements (which run on the YouScope's server) to be able to trigger certain behavior on the client side, e.g. to wait for a certain user input. The client therefore passes a measurement callback provider to the server when creating a new measurement. Measurements or jobs can than ask the provider for a certain functionality, represented by an interface. If the functionality is available, an object implementing the interface is returned, which can be used for communication proposes. Note that the structure of YouScope discourages the use of such callbacks. In general, measurements should be run without user interaction, or even without any client connected (the client can disconnect after starting a measurement, and the measurement should continue to run). However, for certain use cases callbacks are necessary, but the respective measurement is then responsible to check the availability of the callback, provide certain default behavior, and also include appropriate methods for the case that a client disconnects certainly during a measurement. Furthermore, a callback interface should be defined general, i.e. be not dependent on a certain type of client, and in no case be used to obtain direct control over the client. On the other hand, the client should not directly communicate with the microscope during a measurement. A typical usecase would thus be that the measurement takes an image and sends it via the callback to the client. The implementation of the callback querries the user in one or the other way about certain properties of the image, e.g. if the quality is good enough. The callback implementation then just returns the answer to the measurement (e.g. a boolean value).

Author:
Moritz Lang

Method Summary
 void initializeCallback()
          Has to be called by the measurement or job upon initialization prior to using any functionality of the callback (except pingCallback()).
 void pingCallback()
          Checks the connection to the callback.
 void uninitializeCallback()
          Has to be called by the measurement or job upon uninitialization.
 

Method Detail

pingCallback

void pingCallback()
                  throws java.rmi.RemoteException
Checks the connection to the callback. The implementation should be empty, i.e. return immediately without any action. The function can thus be used by a measurement to check if the callback is still available.

Throws:
java.rmi.RemoteException

initializeCallback

void initializeCallback()
                        throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                               MeasurementCallbackException
Has to be called by the measurement or job upon initialization prior to using any functionality of the callback (except pingCallback()). Must not be called already upon creation of the job/measurement.

Throws:
java.rmi.RemoteException
MeasurementCallbackException

uninitializeCallback

void uninitializeCallback()
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                 MeasurementCallbackException
Has to be called by the measurement or job upon uninitialization. After calling this function, no functionality of the callback is allowed to be used anymore (except pingCallback()) until reinitialization.

Throws:
java.rmi.RemoteException
MeasurementCallbackException
